title: 113_s2209
content: The Act may be cited as the "Syrian War Crimes Accountability Act of 2014". Congress finds escalating violence in Syria, with over 140,000 deaths, including 10,000 children. President Assad used sarin gas and artillery, killing over 1,000 people in East Ghouta and Moadamiya al-Sham. Pro-government forces have attacked Syrian civilians. Government forces in Syria have attacked civilian populations using murder, torture, assault, and rape as war tactics. Anti-government groups have also committed murder, torture, hostage-taking, and attacks on protected objects. International rules of war require distinguishing between civilians and combatants and ensuring medical neutrality for unhindered access to medical care. The Sense of Congress is stated in Section 3. Congress strongly condemns ongoing violence, use of chemical weapons, and human rights violations in Syria, supports democratic change, urges halting attacks on civilians, and calls for accountability for war crimes. Congress strongly condemns ongoing violence, use of chemical weapons, and human rights violations in Syria, supports democratic change, urges halting attacks on civilians, and calls for accountability for war crimes. Additionally, it calls for a United Nations Security Council investigation into gross violations of human rights and war crimes committed during the Syrian conflict. SEC. 4. REPORT ON ACCOUNTABILITY FOR WAR CRIMES AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY IN SYRIA. The Secretary of State must submit a report on war crimes and crimes against humanity in Syria within 90 days of the enactment of the Act and again within 180 days after the violence in Syria ends. The report must include descriptions of violations of human rights and crimes against humanity during the civil war, including those committed by President Bashar al-Assad's regime and violent extremist groups. The report must include descriptions of efforts by the Department of State and the United States Agency for International Development to ensure accountability for violations of human rights and crimes against humanity in Syria, including initiatives to train investigators on documenting war crimes. The report must include findings of war crimes, efforts to ensure accountability for crimes committed during the Syrian conflict, and an assessment of the impact of these initiatives. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refer to the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate and the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives.
